etymology: Borrowed from a Czech číše (“cup”), from Proto-Slavic *čaša.[1][2]

translations.value: cup ( a concave vessel for drinking from )
girl
daughter

etymology: From Proto-Finno-Ugric *teke-. Cognates include Finnish tehdä, Karelian tehtä and Estonian tegema. [1][2]

translations.value: (transitive)  to do ( optionally with -val/-vel for the target person or object )
translations.example: Tedd azt, amit mondok! ― Do what I say!

translations.value: (transitive)  to place , to put ( with lative suffixes )
(transitive)  to make ( to cause to be; with the result in -vá/-vé )
(intransitive)  to see to it , to ensure ( followed by the adverb róla )
translations.example: Majd teszek róla, hogy meggondolja magát. ― I'll see to it that he changes his mind.

translations.value: (intransitive, construed with -het)  to (be able to) help  it, to be the cause  of, to be to blame  (potential form with -ról/-ről  or followed by the adverb )
translations.example: Nem tehetek róla, hogy beteg vagyok. ― I can’t help it if I’m sick.

etymology: From Proto-Uralic *mene-. Cognates include Mansi мини (mini), Finnish mennä and Estonian minna.

translations.value: (intransitive)  to go , travel ( whether on foot or by any vehicle )
(intransitive)  to work , operate , function
(intransitive, chiefly with így (“in this way”))  to happen , turn out
(intransitive, informal)  to succeed ( to turn out successfully )
(intransitive)  to fit  onto or into something ( with -ra/-re or -ba/-be )
(intransitive, of thorn, splinter, dirt, insects, etc.)  to get into ( with -ba/-be )
(intransitive, of programmes, shows, performances)  to be on
(intransitive)  to go with , match ( with -hoz/-hez/-höz )
(intransitive, with professions)  to become ( with -nak/-nek )
(intransitive, of time)  to go by , pass by
beautiful
(as a prefix) great-great -great-grand- ( the grandparent of one's great-grandparent or the grandchild of one's great-grandchild )
